questions.question_text:
During the planning stage of a project the project manager realizes that a standard stakeholder engagement approach will not suffice. One of the client representatives, who is not a key decision maker, is extremely opinionated. This client representative could become a roadblock to progress due to their perceived level of authority during meetings.
How should the project manager handle this moving forward?

comments.content: remove my upvote. I think it is B. & E. safer and more realistic is my reasoning. D. is not realistic as a PM.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
i would pick DE, try getting their buy in but if it fails i need a mitigation plan if they really sue

Selected Answer: BD
To handle this kind of stakeholder resistance, the project manager should:

Communicate benefits clearly (B)

Engage directly and consistently with stakeholders (D)

Selected Answer: BD
By focusing on communication, engagement, and transparency (Options B and D), the project manager can address resistance, manage stakeholder expectations, and work towards a successful project outcome.

B. Publish information on the city's website about the benefits that the new tram station will bring
E. Register this situation as a risk and develop a mitigation plan

B is important because proactively communicating the benefits of the project to the community can help address concerns, reduce resistance, and build public support. By providing transparent information, the city can educate residents about the positive impact of the new tram station and counteract the negative perceptions.
E is essential because the threat of legal action from the neighbors represents a potential risk to the project. Registering this as a risk and developing a mitigation plan allows the project team to prepare for possible outcomes and implement strategies to minimize the risk of project delays or cancellation.

Selected Answer: BD
The problem has already occurred and has become an issue.

So, if we were to prioritize the options based on the severity and immediacy of the issue (legal threats), then option E would indeed be one of the top actions to take, alongside direct engagement with the neighbors (option D) to address and potentially alleviate their concerns.

The construction and infrastructure work will be accomplished using a predictive life cycle while software will be developed using an iterative life cycle. Some neighbors are resisting the project have been asking the mayor to stop the project, and are threatening legal action.
What two actions should the project manager take'? (Choose two.)

B. Evaluate their own strengths and weaknesses as a virtual team leader to identify avoidable pitfalls. Self-assessment will help the project manager develop strategies to overcome their weaknesses and capitalize on their strengths, ensuring a more effective virtual team leadership.

D. Establish in the beginning how progress will be monitored and the best means for communicating progress. Setting clear expectations and communication methods from the outset is crucial for virtual teams, as it helps ensure everyone stays informed and engaged, even when working remotely.
